The TypeScript Framework for Vibe Coding - Full-stack, type-safe, AI-friendly.
The TypeScript framework designed for AI-assisted development. Predictable conventions, end-to-end type safety, zero ambiguity.

import { Card, CardGrid } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';

## Why VibeonRails?

<CardGrid stagger>
  <Card title="End-to-End Type Safety" icon="approve-check">
    From database schema to API endpoints to frontend components. TypeScript everywhere, no `any` allowed.
  </Card>
  <Card title="Convention over Configuration" icon="setting">
    Predictable file structure, naming conventions, and patterns. Every folder has a SKILL.md that teaches you (and AI agents) how to use it.
  </Card>
  <Card title="AI-Native" icon="rocket">
    Built for AI-assisted development. Clear patterns, zero ambiguity, SKILL.md documentation in every package.
  </Card>
  <Card title="Full-Stack" icon="laptop">
    API (Hono + tRPC), Database (Drizzle ORM), Security (JWT + Argon2), Frontend (React), Infrastructure (queues, email, cache, storage).
  </Card>
</CardGrid>

## The Stack

| Layer | Technology | Why |
|-------|-----------|-----|
| **HTTP Server** | Hono | Fast, edge-ready, middleware support |
| **API Layer** | tRPC | End-to-end type safety, no code generation |
| **Database** | Drizzle ORM | Type-safe SQL, migrations, zero overhead |
| **Validation** | Zod | Schema validation, type inference |
| **Auth** | jose + Argon2 | JWT tokens, secure password hashing |
| **Queue** | BullMQ | Redis-based background jobs |
| **Email** | Resend | Transactional email delivery |
| **Frontend** | React | Component library, hooks, CSS system |
| **Testing** | Vitest | Fast, TypeScript-native test runner |
| **CLI** | Custom | Project scaffolding, code generators |

## Quick Example

```typescript
// Create a type-safe API endpoint in 30 seconds
import { createServer, createRouter, publicProcedure } from '@vibeonrails/core/api';
import { z } from 'zod';

const appRouter = createRouter({
  hello: publicProcedure
    .input(z.object({ name: z.string() }))
    .query(({ input }) => {
      return { message: `Hello, ${input.name}!` };
    }),
});

const server = createServer({ router: appRouter });
export default server;
```

import { Tabs, TabItem } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';

## Prerequisites

Before you begin, make sure you have the following installed:

| Tool | Version | Purpose |
|------|---------|---------|
| **Node.js** | 22+ | JavaScript runtime |
| **pnpm** | 9+ | Package manager (recommended) |
| **PostgreSQL** | 15+ | Primary database |
| **Redis** | 7+ | Queue and cache (optional for basic apps) |

### Install pnpm

If you do not have pnpm installed:

```bash
corepack enable
corepack prepare pnpm@latest --activate
```

### Install PostgreSQL

<Tabs>
  <TabItem label="macOS">
    ```bash
    brew install postgresql@16
    brew services start postgresql@16
    ```
  </TabItem>
  <TabItem label="Docker">
    ```bash
    docker run -d \
      --name vibeonrails-db \
      -e POSTGRES_DB=my_app \
      -e POSTGRES_PASSWORD=postgres \
      -p 5432:5432 \
      postgres:16
    ```
  </TabItem>
  <TabItem label="Linux">
    ```bash
    sudo apt install postgresql-16
    sudo systemctl start postgresql
    ```
  </TabItem>
</Tabs>

## Option 1: Create a New Project (Recommended)

The fastest way to get started is with the `create-vibe` CLI:

```bash
npx create-vibe my-app
```

You will be prompted to choose a template:

- **basic** - Minimal API server with authentication and posts
- **saas** - Full SaaS starter with payments, admin panel, email, and queue

```bash
# Create a SaaS starter directly
npx create-vibe my-app --template saas
```

Then install dependencies and start:

```bash
cd my-app
pnpm install
```

## Option 2: Add to an Existing Project

If you have an existing TypeScript project, install the packages you need:

```bash
# Core (API + Database + Security)
pnpm add @vibeonrails/core

# Infrastructure (logging, queue, email, cache, etc.)
pnpm add @vibeonrails/infra

# Frontend (components, hooks, CSS)
pnpm add @vibeonrails/web

# CLI tools
pnpm add -D @vibeonrails/cli
```

## Environment Setup

Create a `.env` file in your project root:

```bash
# Server
PORT=3000
NODE_ENV=development

# Database
DATABASE_URL=postgresql://postgres:postgres@localhost:5432/my_app

# Security
JWT_SECRET=your-secret-key-change-this-in-production-at-least-32-chars
JWT_ISSUER=my-app

# Redis (optional - for queue and cache)
REDIS_URL=redis://localhost:6379
```

:::caution
Never commit your `.env` file to git. Make sure it is in your `.gitignore`.
:::

## Database Setup

Create your database and run migrations:

```bash
# Create the database
createdb my_app

# Run migrations
pnpm vibe db migrate

# Seed development data
pnpm vibe db seed
```

## Verify Installation

Start the development server:

```bash
pnpm dev
```

Test that everything is working:

```bash
curl http://localhost:3000/health
```

You should see:

```json
{
  "status": "ok",
  "timestamp": "2026-02-05T12:00:00.000Z",
  "version": "0.1.0"
}
```

What is VibeonRails and why should you use it?

import { Card, CardGrid } from '@astrojs/starlight/components';

## What is VibeonRails?

VibeonRails is a **full-stack TypeScript framework** designed for AI-assisted development. It combines the best tools in the TypeScript ecosystem into a cohesive, convention-driven experience that is predictable for both humans and AI agents.

Think of it as **Rails for TypeScript**  opinionated defaults, clear conventions, and everything you need to ship production applications fast.

## Core Principles

<CardGrid>
  <Card title="Convention over Configuration" icon="setting">
    Sensible defaults for everything. Override when you need to, but the defaults work out of the box. Every project follows the same structure.
  </Card>
  <Card title="End-to-End Type Safety" icon="approve-check">
    From your database schema through your API layer to your frontend components, everything is fully typed. No `any`, no runtime surprises.
  </Card>
  <Card title="AI-Agent Friendly" icon="rocket">
    Every folder has a `SKILL.md` file that teaches AI agents (and developers) how to use it. Predictable patterns mean predictable AI assistance.
  </Card>
  <Card title="Modular Architecture" icon="puzzle">
    Use only what you need. Every package is independent and tree-shakeable. Start minimal, add features as you grow.
  </Card>
</CardGrid>

## The Technology Stack

VibeonRails is not a new framework from scratch. It is a carefully curated integration of proven, production-ready tools:

| Layer | Tool | Why This Tool |
|-------|------|---------------|
| **HTTP Server** | [Hono](https://hono.dev) | Fastest TypeScript server, runs on edge, Node.js, Bun, Deno |
| **API Layer** | [tRPC](https://trpc.io) | End-to-end type safety without code generation or schemas |
| **Database** | [Drizzle ORM](https://orm.drizzle.team) | Type-safe SQL with zero runtime overhead, great migrations |
| **Validation** | [Zod](https://zod.dev) | Schema validation with automatic TypeScript type inference |
| **Authentication** | [jose](https://github.com/panva/jose) + [Argon2](https://github.com/ranisalt/node-argon2) | JWT token management + secure password hashing |
| **Queue** | [BullMQ](https://bullmq.io) | Redis-based background jobs with retries, scheduling, priorities |
| **Email** | [Resend](https://resend.com) | Modern email API for transactional emails |
| **Frontend** | [React](https://react.dev) | Component library with hooks, CSS system, tRPC client |
| **Testing** | [Vitest](https://vitest.dev) | Fast, TypeScript-native test runner with great DX |
| **Build** | [tsup](https://tsup.egoist.dev) | Zero-config TypeScript bundler |

## Who is VibeonRails For?

- **Solo developers** who want to ship fast without making architectural decisions
- **Teams** who want consistency across projects and developers
- **AI-assisted development** workflows where predictability matters
- **TypeScript developers** who want a full-stack framework, not a collection of libraries
- **Startups** building MVPs and SaaS products

## Package Overview

VibeonRails is organized as a monorepo with focused packages:

| Package | What It Does |
|---------|-------------|
| `@vibeonrails/core` | API server (Hono + tRPC), Database (Drizzle ORM), Security (JWT, sessions, OAuth) |
| `@vibeonrails/infra` | Health checks, logging, queues, email, caching, file storage, real-time, monitoring |
| `@vibeonrails/web` | CSS design system, React components, hooks, client-side routing |
| `@vibeonrails/cli` | Project scaffolding, code generators, dev server, database tools |
| `@vibeonrails/payments` | Stripe integration: checkout, subscriptions, webhooks |
| `@vibeonrails/admin` | Auto-generated CRUD admin panel |
| `@vibeonrails/support` | Ticket system, knowledge base, live chat |
| `@vibeonrails/sales` | AI sales agent, multi-channel communication |
| `@vibeonrails/marketing` | Content generation, social scheduling, email sequences |

The design principles behind VibeonRails and why they matter.

VibeonRails is not just a collection of libraries. It is an opinionated framework with a clear philosophy about how TypeScript applications should be built. Understanding these principles helps you work with the framework instead of against it.

## Convention over Configuration

The single most important principle. Inspired by Ruby on Rails, VibeonRails provides sensible defaults for everything:

- **File naming**: `user.service.ts`, `user.controller.ts`, `user.types.ts`
- **Folder structure**: `src/modules/<name>/` for every feature
- **Database patterns**: Repository pattern, migrations in `drizzle/`, seeds in `seeds/`
- **Testing**: Colocated tests (`feature.test.ts` next to `feature.ts`)
- **Exports**: Barrel pattern (`index.ts` in every folder)

You do not need to configure these conventions. They are the framework. When you follow them, everything works. When you need to break a convention, you can, but the defaults handle 95% of cases.

## End-to-End Type Safety

Types flow through your entire application:

1. **Database schema** (Drizzle) defines the shape of your data
2. **Zod schemas** validate input at the API boundary
3. **tRPC procedures** carry types from server to client
4. **React components** receive typed props from tRPC queries

A change to your database schema creates TypeScript errors everywhere that needs updating. No runtime surprises, no `any` types, no manual type synchronization.

## AI-Agent Friendly

VibeonRails is designed to be used with AI coding assistants. This means:

- **Predictable patterns**: AI agents can predict where code lives and how it should look
- **SKILL.md everywhere**: Every package and folder has documentation that AI agents can read
- **Clear boundaries**: Services handle logic, controllers handle HTTP, types handle schemas
- **No magic**: No decorators, no reflection, no runtime code generation. What you see is what runs.

## Modular by Default

Every feature is a self-contained module. Modules:

- Have their own types, logic, endpoints, and tests
- Export a clean public API through `index.ts`
- Can be generated with `vibe generate module <name>`
- Can be removed by deleting the folder and removing the router registration

## Test-Driven Development

VibeonRails encourages TDD:

1. **Write a failing test** (RED)
2. **Write the minimal implementation** (GREEN)
3. **Refactor** (IMPROVE)

The CLI generates test files alongside source files. The validate script runs tests as part of the CI pipeline. When tests fail, fix the implementation, not the tests (unless the test is wrong).

Understand the file and folder layout of a VibeonRails project.

When you scaffold a new VibeonRails project, you get a well-organized structure that follows the convention-over-configuration philosophy. Every file has a purpose, every folder has a pattern.

## Top-Level Structure

```
my-app/
 src/                    # Application source code
    config/             # Configuration files
    modules/            # Feature modules (your business logic)
    router.ts           # Merges all module routers
    main.ts             # Entry point  creates and starts the server
 drizzle/                # Database migration files (auto-generated)
 seeds/                  # Database seed data
 .env                    # Environment variables (not committed)
 .env.example            # Example environment file (committed)
 drizzle.config.ts       # Drizzle Kit configuration
 package.json            # Dependencies and scripts
 tsconfig.json           # TypeScript configuration
 vitest.config.ts        # Test runner configuration
 SKILL.md                # AI agent documentation for this project
 .plan/                  # Planning documents (optional)
     SKILL.md            # How to use the planning system
```

## The `src/` Directory

### `src/config/`

Application configuration files. These read from environment variables and export typed configuration objects.

```typescript
// src/config/app.config.ts
export const appConfig = {
  port: Number(process.env.PORT) || 3000,
  env: process.env.NODE_ENV || 'development',
  name: 'my-app',
};
```

### `src/modules/`

This is where your application code lives. Each feature is a **module**  a self-contained folder with a consistent file structure.

```
src/modules/
 auth/                   # Authentication module
    auth.types.ts       # Zod schemas and TypeScript types
    auth.service.ts     # Business logic
    auth.controller.ts  # tRPC procedures (API endpoints)
    auth.test.ts        # Tests
    index.ts            # Barrel export
 user/                   # User management module
    user.types.ts
    user.service.ts
    user.controller.ts
    user.test.ts
    index.ts
 post/                   # Blog post module
     post.types.ts
     post.service.ts
     post.controller.ts
     post.test.ts
     index.ts
```

### Module File Conventions

Every module follows the same 5-file pattern:

| File | Purpose | Contains |
|------|---------|----------|
| `*.types.ts` | Data shapes | Zod schemas, TypeScript types, input/output types |
| `*.service.ts` | Business logic | Database queries, data transformations, validations |
| `*.controller.ts` | API endpoints | tRPC procedures that call the service |
| `*.test.ts` | Tests | Unit tests for the service and integration tests for the controller |
| `index.ts` | Public API | Barrel export of the router and types |

### `src/router.ts`

Merges all module routers into a single tRPC router:

```typescript
import { createAppRouter } from '@vibeonrails/core/api';
import { authRouter } from './modules/auth';
import { userRouter } from './modules/user';
import { postRouter } from './modules/post';

export const appRouter = createAppRouter({
  auth: authRouter,
  user: userRouter,
  post: postRouter,
});

export type AppRouter = typeof appRouter;
```

### `src/main.ts`

The entry point that creates and starts the server:

```typescript
import { createServer } from '@vibeonrails/core/api';
import { appRouter } from './router';

const server = createServer({ router: appRouter });

export default server;
```

## The `SKILL.md` Convention

Every VibeonRails project (and every package in the framework) contains a `SKILL.md` file. This file:

1. Explains what the folder/package does
2. Shows the file structure and naming conventions
3. Provides examples of common operations
4. Lists pitfalls and best practices

This makes the codebase navigable by both humans and AI agents. When an AI agent encounters a folder, it reads `SKILL.md` to understand how to work with it.

Create your first VibeonRails app in 5 minutes.

This guide gets you from zero to a running VibeonRails application in under 5 minutes. For a more detailed walkthrough, see the [Your First App](/tutorials/your-first-app/) tutorial.

## 1. Create the Project

```bash
npx create-vibe my-app
cd my-app
pnpm install
```

## 2. Start the Database

```bash
# Using Docker (simplest)
docker run -d --name my-app-db \
  -e POSTGRES_DB=my_app \
  -e POSTGRES_PASSWORD=postgres \
  -p 5432:5432 postgres:16

# Run migrations and seed data
pnpm vibe db migrate
pnpm vibe db seed
```

## 3. Start the Dev Server

```bash
pnpm dev
```

Your API is now running at `http://localhost:3000`.

## 4. Try It Out

```bash
# Health check
curl http://localhost:3000/health

# Register a user
curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/trpc/auth.register \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"json": {"email": "hello@example.com", "password": "securepassword123", "name": "Alice"}}'

# Login
curl -X POST http://localhost:3000/trpc/auth.login \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"json": {"email": "hello@example.com", "password": "securepassword123"}}'
```

## 5. Generate a Module

```bash
pnpm vibe generate module todo
```

This creates a complete module with types, service, controller, tests, and barrel export. Register it in your router:

```typescript
// src/router.ts
import { todoRouter } from './modules/todo';

export const appRouter = createAppRouter({
  // ... existing routes
  todo: todoRouter,
});
```

## 6. Run Tests

```bash
pnpm test
```
